column1: Enschede (Dutch pronunciation: [ˈɛnsxəˌdeː] (listen)
column2: also known as Eanske [ˈɛːnskə] in the local dialect of Twents) is a municipality and city in the eastern Netherlands in the province of Overijssel and in the Twente region. The eastern parts of the urban area reaches the border with Germany. The municipality of Enschede consisted of the city of Enschede until 1935
column3: when the rural municipality of Lonneker
column4: which surrounded the city
column5: was annexed after the rapid industrial expansion of Enschede which began in the 1860s and involved the building of railways and the digging of the Twentekanaal. The proposal for consolidation began in 1872
column6: per the Tubantia newspaper article on 22 Jun 1872 that referenced a committee of 5 to oversea a study.  They were: J. Mosman (Johannes Theodorus Mosman)

column1: In sports and culture
column2: Enschede is perhaps best known for being home to football club FC Twente
column3: one-time Dutch champions and University of Twente.

column1: == Geography ==
Enschede lies in the eastern part of Overijssel and is the easternmost city of more than 140
column2: 000 inhabitants in the Netherlands. The city lies a few kilometres from Germany
column3: which borders the municipality. A few small rivers flow through or surround the city
column4: such as the Roombeek and Glanerbeek.

column1: === Climate ===
Like most of the Netherlands
column2: Enschede features an oceanic climate (Cfb in the Köppen classification)
column3: however
column4: winters tend to be less mild than the rest of the Netherlands due to its inland location. Although the former military airport is derelict and plans to revive the place were canceled in 2012
column5: the Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute still maintains a weather station there.

column1: == History ==
=== Pre-industrialisation ===
The early history of Enschede is largely unknown
column2: but a settlement existed around the Old Marketplace in early medieval times. The name of this settlement is mentioned as Anescede or Enscede meaning either "near the border" (with Bentheim) or "near the Es" and sported a church
column3: a marketplace and a fortified aristocratic house.Enschede was granted city rights around 1300 which were confirmed in 1325 by Bishop Jan III van Diest and henceforth was allowed to protect itself with a wall. Because a stone wall was too expensive (since stone had to be imported)
column4: Enschede had a system of ditches
column6: which is still reflected in the street-names Noorderhagen and Zuiderhagen (North Hedge and South Hedge
column7: respectively). The city plan of this era is still recognisable in the street-pattern. The city was spared destruction in 1597 at its capture during the Eighty Years' War when after a short siege
column8: the Spanish garrison surrendered the city and the defences were razed.

column1: Because the medieval city was largely built of wood and stone houses were the exception
column2: fire was a constant risk and a series of fires in 1517
column3: 1750 and again on 7 May 1862 earned the people from Enschede the nickname Brandstichters (arsonists).

column1: === Industrialisation ===
The last fire coincided with the start of the growth of the city into a large production center of textiles
column2: originally as a cottage industry
column3: but since the start of the 19th century on an industrial scale
column4: especially the manufacture of bombazijn (a mixture of cotton and linen) proved a successful export. One such factory to have produced textiles in the late 19th century is the Hardick & Seckel Factory.

column1: The industrialisation stimulated a large increase in population
column2: which by 1894 had reached an estimated 18
column3: 267: nineteenth-century urban growth was at first rather chaotic. The names of the slums (like De Krim and Sebastopol) are still notorious
column4: although they have long since been torn down. In 1907 the laissez faire mentality was dropped and Enschede was the first city in the Netherlands to draw up an official expansion-plan
column5: incorporating the surrounding municipality of Lonneker.

column1: === World War II ===
During the Second World War Enschede was one of the first Dutch cities to be captured by German troops
column2: being the city closest to Germany. Resistance members helped many of the Jews from Enschede to hide on farms in the vicinity. Out of approximately 1300 Jews in Enschede
column3: 500 were saved (38.5%)
column4: compared to less than 20% in the rest of the Netherlands. This higher survival rate is attributed to three members of the Jewish Council of Enschede
column6: Gerard Sanders and Isidoor Van Dam who took the initiative
column7: against the advice of the Jewish Council of Amsterdam
column8: of urging their community to go into hiding and not to answer the call-up of the Germans for "labour in the East".

column1: Enschede was bombed on several occasions
column2: most notably on October 10
column3: 1943 and February 22
column4: 1944. During the first raid the nearby airport (then Fliegerhorst Twente) was a target of opportunity for the VIII Bomber Command during a raid on rail- and waterways in Münster. 141 people died and many houses were damaged. The latter mission named Enschede as a target of opportunity during Big Week after bombers had been recalled due to adverse weather.

column1: === The end of the industrial age ===
In the 1970s the textile production in Enschede came to a halt
column2: due to fierce competition from mainly the Far East. This had a profound effect on the populace. Enschede became one of the poorest municipalities in the Netherlands and went bankrupt. Large areas of industrial wasteland came to mark the city. With the support of the national government
column3: this property was acquired and rebuilt. The city center was rendered a car-free zone.

column1: In 1961 it was announced a third technical university would be founded
column2: placed on an estate on the western border of Enschede. This green campus called Drienerlo was donated by the city of Enschede. Building was complete in 1964
column3: when the first and only full-facility university of the Netherlands was realised.

column1: On 13 May 2000
column2: a fireworks storage depot in Enschede exploded
column3: destroying part of the neighborhood of Roombeek and killing 23 people
column4: including 4 firemen. In 2001 a referendum confirmed the proposal of the city council to expand the built-up area into the Usseler Es
column5: an area of historic cultural significance and of geological importance
column6: as it was here that the Usselo horizon was discovered. The renovations at Roombeek were finished in the year 2012. The place where the factory used to be is now a monument.

column1: == Religion ==
The largest religion in Enschede is Christianity with 34.9% of the population being Christian.
Enschede has a large Assyrian community
column2: the first Assyrians came to Enschede in the 1970s
column3: primarily from Turkey (Tur-Abdin). That is why there are today three syriac orthodox churches in Enschede which meets the spiritual needs of the approximately over 10'000 Assyrians of the city.

column1: == Economy ==
The city is a former centre of textile production. When this industry left the area for cheaper production centers in South-East Asia
column2: Enschede became one of the poorest municipalities in the Netherlands. More educated and wealthy citizens have historically migrated to the Randstad region; decades of renovation work in the city center have been carried out with the goal of making Enschede more attractive to this group.

column1: Modern shopping centers and department stores that until recently were only found in much larger cities have been opened. Enschede is host to many yearly festivals and the Old Market Square is often the venue for events
column2: live music and other activities on the weekend.

column1: The proximity to Germany has
column2: historically
column3: been another major factor in the city's economic activity
column4: ranging from the smuggling of coffee and tobacco in the 19th and 20th century
column6: who visit the city's shops and weekly markets. Therefore
column7: many natives of Enschede speak German more or less fluently.The city is co-operating with the nearby municipalities of Almelo
column8: Borne and Hengelo as Netwerkstad Twente. A draft law plan to merge Enschede with Hengelo and Almelo was defeated in parliament under the influence of opposition from the other towns.

column1: Grolsch beer is brewed in Enschede
column2: and the tyre manufacturer Apollo Vredestein B.V. head office and a factory is in the city. It is one of the most important employers of the region.

column1: == Research
column2: education and health care ==

column1: The Universiteit Twente (University of Twente)
column2: a university with mostly technical studies
column3: is located in Enschede. It is one of the four technical universities in the Netherlands (besides Delft University of Technology
column4: Eindhoven University of Technology and the Wageningen University and Research Centre). The Universiteit Twente is also the only large-campus university in the Netherlands.

column1: The university has courses in pure technical studies such as Applied Physics
column2: Applied Mathematics
column3: Mechanical Engineering
column4: Electrical Engineering
column6: Informatics/Computer Science and Industrial Engineering and also offers study programmes in Communication
column11: Applied Medicine and Biomedical Technology; the latter attract a broader public. Since 2006
column14: Creative Technology and ATLAS University College have been added to the university's offerings.

column1: Enschede is also home to one of the three campuses of Saxion University of Applied Sciences (Saxion Hogeschool Enschede)
column2: a polytechnical school offering internationally recognized Bachelor's degrees and Master's degrees in a wide range of fields
column3: including engineering
column4: economics
column6: investigations and health care. The other campuses are located in Deventer and Apeldoorn.

column1: The Faculty of Geo-Information Science and Earth Observation of the University of Twente
column2: with former name International  Institute for Aerospace Survey and Earth Sciences
column3: (known by its abbreviation ITC) runs MSc
column4: Master's
column5: Diploma and PhD courses in Geo-Information Science for developing countries. Students from all over the world attend the ITC. Enschede also has an academy of arts and design combined with a conservatory named ArtEZ.

column1: The Medisch Spectrum Twente (MST) hospital is one of the largest top-clinical hospitals of the Netherlands and features important tertiary care departments
column2: fulfilling a supraregional role. It includes a level I trauma center as well. The hospital is strongly involved in higher medical education
column3: with up to 300 medical students following their internships in the hospital at any given time
column4: closely working together with the University of Twente's Technical Medicine program training a new type of technically specialized doctors.

column1: == Transport ==
Enschede is a terminus station of the Nederlandse Spoorwegen (NS) railway lines from the west. Trains operate to Hengelo
column2: Almelo
column3: Zwolle
column4: Deventer
column11: Rotterdam Centraal and Den Haag Centraal.

column1: To the east there is a line to Gronau
column2: Germany
column3: which has two more stations in the Netherlands: Enschede De Eschmarke and Glanerbrug. The latter two have low ridership. The line is served by

column1: DB Regionalbahn Westfalen (part of the German Deutsche Bahn)
column2: to Münster and to Dortmund
column3: each on an hourly interval and alternating half-hours in the service to Gronau.

column1: There is no track connection between the two systems. The through line had been retained for eventual NATO use during the Cold War even after through passenger service was ended (September 1981)
column2: although it was in serious disrepair in later years. With the renewal of service to Germany (May 2001) the track was severed; there is a gap of about 30 centimeters between them.There is also Enschede Kennispark railway station
column3: near the football stadium.

column1: Enschede is situated at the south-east terminus of the Twentekanaal. There is also a network of bus lines connecting nearly every part of the city with the centre. Enschede also has bus connections to nearby towns and cities
column2: like Hengelo
column3: Oldenzaal and south towards Haaksbergen
column4: Neede and Eibergen. The city lines are operated by Syntus
column5: under the Twents-branche. The interlocal lines are exploited by Syntus and Arriva.

column1: Previously
column2: Enschede had a combined regional civil airport
column3: Enschede Airport
column4: and  Airbase Twenthe of the Royal Netherlands Air Force. The latter was closed in 2007; the former was closed in 2008.

column1: == Culture ==
There are several museums in Enschede
column2: among them the Rijksmuseum Twenthe for art.  A museum of natural history and a museum dedicated to the history of the textiles industry
column3: both closed in January 2007
column4: have merged
column5: and have reopened in April 2008 in new premises on a new location under the name TwentseWelle (Source/Well of Twente). The new location is situated in Roombeek
column6: where a fireworks disaster took place in 2000. The new museum is located partly in a renovated old textile factory
column7: in reference to Enschede's textile history
column8: and partly in an adjourning new building
column9: designed by the Amsterdam-based firm SeARCH (project architect: Bjarne Mastenbroek). Besides museums there are also several art spaces
column10: the most prominent being Villa de Bank and TETEM. The latter focuses on art and technology
column11: and aims to be accessible for a wide public.

column1: Enschede is also home of The Netherlands Symphony Orchestra.
In December 2012
column2: the Serious Request action from national radio station 3FM took place in Enschede
column3: which collected more than 12.2 million euros (almost US$16.2 million).

column1: == Sports ==
Enschede's association football club is FC Twente. Twente were the 2010 Eredivisie champions but were relegated to the second-tier league
column2: the Eerste Divisie
column3: after the 2017-18 season. Since the 2019–2020 season
column4: they are back in the Eredivisie.

column1: The oldest marathon of the Netherlands
column2: and the second oldest of Europe
column3: is the Enschede Marathon. The student rowing club D.R.V. Euros has produced several national champions and one Olympic Champion. DOS-WK played until 2006 in the highest competition of korfball
column4: the 'Korfbal League'.

column1: Enschede (Old Church to University) is the final stage of the Batavierenrace
column2: a footrace relay beginning in Nijmegen
column3: contested mostly by university student teams and claimed to be the largest relay races in the world
column4: with 8000 participants. Enschede built the second indoor speed skating arena in the country
